title: Water Pressure and Fountains
content:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This dynamic photo shows a fountain with water shooting upward! You can see streams or jets of water spraying into the air, creating beautiful arcs and patterns. The water rises high above the fountain base before gravity pulls it back down. Some water droplets might catch the light, creating sparkles. The fountain demonstrates how water under pressure can be forced upward, defying gravity temporarily before falling back down!

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This image demonstrates water pressure and projectile motion. Water pressure is the force that water exerts when it's confined or compressed. In a fountain, a pump creates pressure that forces water upward through pipes and nozzles. The narrower the opening (nozzle), the faster and higher the water shoots - this is because the same amount of water is being pushed through a smaller space. Once the water leaves the nozzle, it becomes a projectile, following a curved path. Gravity constantly pulls the water downward while the initial upward force gives it height. The shape of the water arc (parabola) is determined by the initial speed and angle. This same principle applies to throwing a ball or shooting a basketball!

## üìö Core Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force exerted by water when it's confined or moving through pipes.

2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path of an object launched into the air and affected by gravity.

3. **Force and Motion**: Pressure provides upward force; gravity provides downward force.

<pedagogical-tip>
Create a "Water Fountain Investigation"! Poke holes at different heights in the side of a plastic bottle filled with water (hole at bottom, middle, top). Students predict: Which hole shoots water farthest? Test outside or over a sink. Students observe: Bottom hole shoots farthest (more water pressure!). Extension: Make squeeze-bottle fountains by filling bottles and squeezing. Measure fountain height with different squeeze forces. Graph pressure vs. height. This hands-on experiment makes invisible water pressure visible and measurable!
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Outdoor Observation**: Watch real fountains, sketch water paths
- **Pressure Testing**: Squeeze bottles to create different fountain heights
- **Arc Drawing**: Trace projectile paths on photos or videos
- **Video Analysis**: Use slow-motion to see water droplet paths
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:3-PS2.A]]: Forces and Motion
- [[NGSS:DCI:K-PS2.A]]: Forces and Motion
- [[NGSS:DCI:3-PS2.B]]: Types of Interactions
- [[NGSS:CCC:Cause]]: Pressure causes water to shoot upward; gravity causes it to fall

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What force pushes water upward in a fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. Why does water from the bottom of a water bottle shoot farther than water from the top? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. What path does water follow after it leaves the fountain nozzle? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
4. How is a fountain similar to throwing a ball into the air? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water pressure**: The force water exerts when confined or moving
- **Projectile**: An object launched into the air
- **Arc**: A curved path through the air
- **Gravity**: The force pulling objects downward
- **Pump**: A device that moves fluid by creating pressure

## ‚õ≤ Extension Activities

- Design paper cup fountains by poking holes at different locations
- Calculate maximum height water reaches in fountains
- Research how ancient Roman aqueducts used gravity and pressure
- Investigate how water towers work to provide water pressure to homes

educational.kindergarten:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This image shows a beautiful water fountain with water shooting up high into the air. The water is spraying out in different directions, creating a lovely display with arching streams of water. The fountain is located outside, with trees and buildings visible in the background. The water looks clear and sparkles in the sunlight as it rises up and then falls back down to the base of the fountain.

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This fountain demonstrates the scientific concept of water pressure. When water is pumped through the pipes and nozzles of the fountain, the water is forced upward by the pressure created by the pump. The narrower the opening of the nozzle, the higher and faster the water will shoot up. Once the water leaves the nozzle, it follows a curved path through the air, like a projectile. Gravity pulls the water back down, creating the arching water streams you see in the fountain.

## üìö Core Science Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force that water exerts when it is confined or moving through pipes.
2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path an object takes when it is launched or thrown into the air.
3. **Forces and Motion**: The upward force of water pressure and the downward force of gravity act on the water in the fountain.

<pedagogical-tip>
To help young students understand these concepts, set up a simple water pressure experiment. Fill a plastic bottle with water and poke holes at different heights on the side. Have students predict which hole will shoot the water the farthest, then test it out. Discuss why the water from the bottom hole travels the farthest - it has more water pressure pushing it out. This hands-on activity makes the invisible force of water pressure visible and measurable.
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Outdoor Observation**: Take students to observe real fountains in action and have them sketch the water patterns.
- **Pressure Testing**: Provide squeeze bottles for students to experiment with creating different fountain heights.
- **Arc Drawing**: Have students trace the curved paths of water droplets on photos or videos of fountains.
- **Video Analysis**: Use slow-motion videos to help students see the detailed motion of the water.
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:K-PS2.A]]: Forces and Motion
- [[NGSS:DCI:K-PS2.B]]: Types of Interactions
- [[NGSS:CCC:Cause]]: Water pressure causes the water to shoot upward, while gravity causes it to fall back down.

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What force is pushing the water up in the fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. Why does the water shoot higher from the bottom hole of the water bottle than the top hole? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. Describe the path the water takes as it leaves the fountain. (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
4. How is the movement of the water in the fountain similar to throwing a ball up in the air? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water Pressure**: The force that water exerts when it is confined or moving through pipes.
- **Projectile**: An object that is launched or thrown into the air.
- **Arc**: The curved path an object takes when it is launched or thrown.
- **Gravity**: The force that pulls objects downward towards the Earth.
- **Pump**: A device that moves fluids by creating pressure.

## üå°Ô∏è Extension Activities

- Design your own paper cup fountains by poking holes at different locations.
- Estimate and measure the maximum height the water reaches in the fountain.
- Investigate how ancient aqueducts used gravity and pressure to move water.
- Explore how water towers work to provide water pressure to homes and buildings.
educational.grade1:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This photo shows a beautiful water fountain with streams of water shooting up into the air. The fountain has several nozzles that are spraying water, creating tall arcs and patterns. The water looks sparkling and shimmery as it catches the light. At the base of the fountain, you can see the pool of water that the fountain is drawing from.

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This photo demonstrates the scientific concept of water pressure. When water is pumped through the pipes and nozzles of the fountain, the water pressure forces the water to shoot up into the air, defying gravity for a short time. The narrower the nozzle opening, the higher and faster the water will spray up. As the water leaves the nozzle, it follows a curved, parabolic path, just like a ball or other object thrown into the air. Gravity pulls the water back down, creating the arcs and patterns we see in the fountain.

## üìö Core Science Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force that pushes water through pipes and nozzles, causing it to spray upwards.
2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path that an object, like the water from the fountain, follows when launched into the air.
3. **Gravity**: The force that pulls the water back down to the ground, creating the arcs and patterns.

<pedagogical-tip>
To help 1st graders understand these concepts, encourage hands-on exploration. Set up a simple water fountain using a plastic bottle, some straws or narrow nozzles, and a pump or squeezing action. Have students observe how the water shoots higher when the opening is smaller. Discuss how the water follows a curved path and eventually falls back down due to gravity. This allows students to directly experience the scientific principles at work.
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Multiple Means of Representation**: Use a variety of materials (e.g., bottle, straws, pump) to demonstrate water pressure and projectile motion.
- **Multiple Means of Action and Expression**: Allow students to design and test their own "fountains" using the provided materials.
- **Multiple Means of Engagement**: Encourage students to make predictions, observe, and explain the phenomena they observe.
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:K-PS2.A]]: Forces and Motion
- [[NGSS:DCI:K-PS2.B]]: Types of Interactions
- [[NGSS:CCC:Cause]]: Water pressure causes the water to shoot up, and gravity causes it to fall back down.

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What is pushing the water up in the fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. Why does the water follow a curved path instead of going straight up? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. What happens to the water when it reaches the top of the fountain? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
4. How are fountains similar to throwing a ball in the air? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water Pressure**: The force that pushes water through pipes and nozzles.
- **Projectile**: An object, like the water from the fountain, that is launched into the air.
- **Gravity**: The force that pulls objects, like the water, back down to the ground.
- **Nozzle**: The opening that the water comes out of in the fountain.
- **Pump**: The device that creates the water pressure in the fountain.
- **Arc**: The curved path that the water takes as it is launched into the air.

## üå°Ô∏è Extension Activities

- Create your own mini-fountain using a plastic bottle, straws, and a pump or squeezing action.
- Experiment with different nozzle sizes and observe how it affects the height and pattern of the water.
- Measure the height of the fountain and graph the relationship between water pressure and fountain height.
- Investigate how ancient civilizations used water pressure and gravity to create fountains and aqueducts.
educational.grade2:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This photo shows a beautiful water fountain with streams of water shooting up into the air. The water is spraying out of the fountain in graceful arcs, reaching high above the base. Some of the water droplets are catching the light, making the fountain look sparkly and magical. This fountain is a fun and visually interesting example of how water can be forced upward under pressure, creating an impressive display!

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This fountain demonstrates the scientific concept of water pressure. The pump inside the fountain creates pressure, forcing the water to shoot upward through the fountain's nozzles. The narrower the opening, the higher and faster the water sprays into the air. Once the water leaves the nozzle, it follows a curved, parabolic path due to the force of gravity pulling it back down. The water shoots up for a while before gravity takes over and pulls it back down to the base of the fountain.

## üìö Core Science Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force that water exerts when it is confined or moving through pipes and nozzles.

2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path that an object follows when launched into the air, affected by both the initial upward force and the constant downward pull of gravity.

3. **Forces and Motion**: The upward force of water pressure pushes the water up, while the downward force of gravity pulls it back down, creating the fountain's arc.

<pedagogical-tip>
To help students understand the scientific concepts behind this fountain, try setting up a simple water pressure experiment in the classroom. Fill a plastic bottle with water and poke holes at different heights on the side. Have students predict which hole will shoot the water the farthest, then test it out. Discuss why the water from the bottom hole travels the furthest - it has more water pressure pushing it upward. This hands-on activity will make the invisible forces of water pressure and gravity more visible and tangible for young learners.
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Sensory Engagement**: Allow students to observe real fountains in action, noticing the water's movement and patterns.
- **Multiple Representations**: Use videos, diagrams, and physical models to illustrate the scientific concepts of water pressure and projectile motion.
- **Student Choice**: Encourage students to design their own water pressure experiments, choosing variables to test and ways to measure the results.
- **Scaffolded Support**: Provide sentence starters or graphic organizers to help students articulate their observations and explanations of the scientific phenomena.
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:K-PS2.A]]: Forces and Motion
- [[NGSS:DCI:2-PS1.A]]: Structure and Properties of Matter
- [[NGSS:CCC:Cause]]: Water pressure causes the upward force that creates the fountain's arc

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What force is pushing the water up in the fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. Why does the water shoot higher from the bottom hole of the bottle compared to the top hole? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. How is the path of the water in the fountain similar to the path of a ball thrown into the air? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)
4. If you wanted to make the fountain shoot water higher, what could you change about the pump or nozzle? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water pressure**: The force that water exerts when it is confined or moving
- **Projectile**: An object that is launched into the air
- **Arc**: The curved path that an object follows when launched into the air
- **Gravity**: The force that pulls objects downward
- **Nozzle**: The opening or opening through which the water is forced out of the fountain
- **Pump**: A device that moves fluid by creating pressure

## üå°Ô∏è Extension Activities

- Create your own mini-fountains by poking holes in the side of a plastic bottle filled with water and observe the different water pressure patterns.
- Investigate how the height of a fountain changes when you adjust the pump's power or the size of the nozzle openings.
- Explore how ancient civilizations used gravity and water pressure to build aqueducts and fountains.
- Conduct experiments to measure the maximum height reached by water shot from different fountain nozzle designs.
educational.grade3:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This photo shows a beautiful, towering fountain with water shooting high into the air. You can see the water spraying out in multiple arcs and streams, creating a mesmerizing display. The water rises up several feet before gracefully falling back down, creating a cascading waterfall effect. The fountain is surrounded by a shallow pool, allowing the water to flow back down into the base. The bright sunlight reflects off the water droplets, making them sparkle and glitter as they move through the air.

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This fountain demonstrates the scientific concept of water pressure. Water pressure is the force that water exerts when it is confined or forced to move through a small space. The fountain uses a pump to create high water pressure, which then forces the water up through the fountain's nozzles. As the water leaves the nozzles, it becomes a projectile, following a curved, parabolic path due to the combined effects of the upward force from the pressure and the downward pull of gravity. The narrower the nozzle openings, the higher and faster the water will shoot up, as the same amount of water is forced through a smaller space.

## üìö Core Science Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force that water exerts when it is confined or forced to move through a small space.
2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path that an object, like the water from a fountain, follows when launched into the air and affected by gravity.
3. **Force and Motion**: The upward force from the water pressure and the downward force of gravity work together to create the water's arcing motion.

<pedagogical-tip>
Engage students in a hands-on investigation of water pressure by having them create their own simple fountains. Provide them with plastic bottles, straws, and tape, and challenge them to poke holes at different heights in the bottles and observe how the water shoots out. Encourage them to experiment with different hole sizes and placements to see how it affects the water's trajectory. This interactive activity will help students better understand the concepts of water pressure and projectile motion in a fun, memorable way.
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Visual Aids**: Use slow-motion videos or diagrams to illustrate the water's parabolic path and the forces at work.
- **Kinesthetic Learning**: Allow students to physically create and test their own fountain designs to reinforce the concepts.
- **Multiple Means of Expression**: Encourage students to represent their understanding through drawings, models, or explanatory writing.
- **Scaffolding**: Break down the concepts into smaller, more manageable steps, providing support as needed.
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:3-PS2.A]]: Forces and Motion
- [[NGSS:DCI:3-PS2.B]]: Types of Interactions
- [[NGSS:CCC:Cause]]: Water pressure causes the water to shoot upward, and gravity causes it to fall back down.

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What force is responsible for pushing the water up in the fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. Why does the water follow a curved, parabolic path as it leaves the fountain? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. How would changing the size of the fountain's nozzle openings affect the height and speed of the water's trajectory? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)
4. How is the motion of the water in the fountain similar to the motion of a ball when it is thrown into the air? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water Pressure**: The force that water exerts when it is confined or forced to move through a small space.
- **Projectile**: An object that is launched or thrown into the air.
- **Parabolic Path**: The curved, arc-like trajectory that a projectile follows due to the combined effects of the upward force and the downward pull of gravity.
- **Nozzle**: The opening or spout from which the water is forced out of the fountain.
- **Gravity**: The force that pulls objects downward towards the Earth.
- **Pump**: A device that creates pressure to move fluids, like the water in a fountain.

## üå°Ô∏è Extension Activities

1. Challenge students to design and build their own mini-fountains using simple materials like cups, straws, and tape. Have them experiment with different nozzle sizes and placements to observe how it affects the water's trajectory.
2. Invite students to investigate the science behind ancient Roman aqueducts, which used gravity and water pressure to transport water over long distances.
3. Encourage students to research and learn about how water towers work to provide water pressure and supply in homes and communities.
educational.grade4:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This photo shows a beautiful fountain in a city park. The fountain has several tall, curved jets of water spraying upwards into the air, creating a mesmerizing display. The water appears to defy gravity as it reaches high into the sky before falling back down in a graceful arc. The sunlight catches the water droplets, making them sparkle and shine. It's a stunning example of how water pressure can be used to create an impressive natural-looking fountain.

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This fountain demonstrates the scientific principles of water pressure and projectile motion. The pump at the base of the fountain creates high water pressure, forcing the water up through the fountain's nozzles. The narrower the nozzle, the higher and faster the water shoots up, due to the increased pressure. Once the water leaves the nozzle, it becomes a projectile that follows a curved, parabolic path. Gravity constantly pulls the water back down, but the initial upward force from the water pressure allows the water to reach great heights before falling.

## üìö Core Science Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force exerted by water when it's confined or moving through pipes and nozzles.
2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path that an object, like the water from the fountain, follows when launched into the air and affected by gravity.
3. **Force and Motion**: The upward force of water pressure overcomes the downward force of gravity, allowing the water to shoot up into the air.

<pedagogical-tip>
To help students understand the scientific concepts behind this fountain, consider doing a hands-on investigation where they create their own mini-fountains. Have them poke holes at different heights in the side of a plastic bottle filled with water, and observe how the water pressure affects the height and distance the water shoots out. This will make the invisible concept of water pressure visible and allow students to actively explore the relationship between pressure and motion.
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Sensory Engagement**: Encourage students to observe the fountain in person or through videos, noting the visual and auditory cues that help them understand the scientific phenomena.
- **Flexible Representation**: Provide students with options to represent their understanding, such as drawing diagrams, creating physical models, or writing explanations.
- **Guided Discovery**: Structure the investigation with clear instructions and guiding questions to support student learning, while still allowing for exploration and hands-on discovery.
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:4-PS3.A]]: Definitions of Energy
- [[NGSS:DCI:4-PS3.B]]: Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer
- [[NGSS:CCC:Cause]]: Pressure causes the water to shoot upward; gravity causes it to fall

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What force is responsible for pushing the water up in the fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. How does the shape of the water's path in the fountain compare to the path of a ball that is thrown into the air? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. Why does the water shoot higher when the fountain's nozzle is narrower? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)
4. How could you use the principles of water pressure and projectile motion to design a more effective fountain? (DOK 4: Extended Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water Pressure**: The force exerted by water when it's confined or moving through pipes and nozzles.
- **Projectile**: An object, like the water from the fountain, that is launched into the air and follows a curved path.
- **Parabolic**: The curved, U-shaped path that a projectile follows.
- **Gravity**: The force that pulls objects downward toward the Earth.
- **Nozzle**: The opening or opening through which the water is forced out of the fountain.
- **Pump**: The device that creates the high water pressure in the fountain.

## üå°Ô∏è Extension Activities

1. Design and build your own mini-fountain using a plastic bottle, water, and a straw or small pipe. Test how changing the size or number of holes affects the height and shape of the water spray.
2. Investigate how ancient Roman aqueducts used gravity and water pressure to transport water over long distances.
3. Research modern water towers and how they use water pressure to provide water to homes and buildings.
educational.grade5:
## üì∏ Photo Description

This photo shows a majestic outdoor fountain with multiple jets of water shooting upwards. The water rises high into the air, creating graceful arcs and sparkling droplets that catch the sunlight. The fountain's powerful spray is an impressive demonstration of water pressure and motion.

## üî¨ Scientific Phenomena

This fountain illustrates the scientific principles of water pressure and projectile motion. A pump at the base of the fountain creates high water pressure, forcing the water up through the fountain's narrow nozzles. As the water exits the nozzles, it becomes a projectile, following a curved, parabolic path due to the combination of the initial upward force and the downward pull of gravity. The height and shape of the water arcs are determined by the strength of the water pressure and the fountain's design.

## üìö Core Science Concepts

1. **Water Pressure**: The force exerted by water when it's confined or in motion. Higher pressure creates higher, more powerful water jets.

2. **Projectile Motion**: The curved path an object, like water, takes when launched into the air and affected by gravity.

3. **Force and Motion**: The interplay between the upward force of water pressure and the downward force of gravity determines the shape and height of the water arcs.

<pedagogical-tip>
Engage students in a "Fountain Experiment" by having them create their own mini-fountains using plastic bottles, water, and various nozzle designs. Encourage them to observe how changes in water pressure and nozzle shape affect the height and shape of the water jets. This hands-on exploration will help students develop a deeper understanding of the scientific concepts behind fountains.
</pedagogical-tip>

<udl-suggestions>
- **Visual Aids**: Use slow-motion videos to clearly observe the water's parabolic path and the effects of pressure.
- **Hands-on Exploration**: Allow students to experiment with different nozzle designs and water pressures to discover the relationships between these variables.
- **Collaborative Learning**: Have students work in teams to design and test their own fountain experiments, promoting discussion and peer-to-peer learning.
- **Multimodal Representation**: Encourage students to represent their understanding through drawings, diagrams, and written explanations, catering to diverse learning preferences.
</udl-suggestions>

## üéì NGSS Connections

- [[NGSS:DCI:5-PS2.B]]: Types of Interactions (Gravity)
- [[NGSS:DCI:5-PS1.A]]: Structure and Properties of Matter (Properties of Fluids)
- [[NGSS:CCC:Systems]]: The fountain as a system with interacting components (water pressure, nozzle, gravity)

## üí¨ Discussion Questions

1. What force is responsible for pushing the water upward in the fountain? (DOK 1: Recall)
2. How does the shape of the water jets change as the water leaves the fountain nozzle? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
3. How does the water pressure affect the height of the water jets? (DOK 2: Skill/Concept)
4. If you were to design your own fountain, what modifications would you make to change the way the water moves? (DOK 3: Strategic Thinking)

## üìñ Vocabulary

- **Water Pressure**: The force exerted by water when it's confined or in motion.
- **Projectile Motion**: The curved path an object, like water, takes when launched into the air.
- **Gravity**: The force that pulls objects downward toward the Earth.
- **Nozzle**: The opening or spout through which water is released from the fountain.
- **Parabolic**: The curved, arc-like shape of the water jets, similar to the path of a thrown object.
- **Pump**: The mechanism that creates the high water pressure in the fountain.

## üå°Ô∏è Extension Activities

1. Investigate how the design of the fountain's nozzles affects the height and shape of the water jets.
2. Measure the maximum height of the water jets and calculate the initial velocity needed to achieve that height.
3. Explore how ancient civilizations used gravity and water pressure to create impressive fountain displays.
4. Design and build a simple water fountain using household materials, testing different nozzle designs and water pressures.
